reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gXjtuVCSZPw&list=UURLmXiAxqgzAGPO64W78sSg

The 2D beat-up genre was a giant during the 8 and 16 bit generations, as well as dominating arcades with their quarter munching gameplay and cooperative game design. With the decline of arcades and the birth of new genres in 3d, the popularity of beat 'em ups waned, making way for new gaming zeitgeists. In recent years the 2D beat-em up has settled for reboots of classics with little success, luckily the love for the genre burns in the hearts of indie developers and with this, Aces Wild Manic Brawling Action comes to life. Does this beat 'em up deliver a first round knock out punch or does it feel like being roughed up and having your lunch money taken away by a bully?

Taking control of the title character Aces Wild, who must participate in this year's Maximus Circuit in an attempt to preserve the lands held by the Wilder Family. His brother Rex has struck a deal with key entrants of the tournament to ensure his victory so he can sell the lands for a hefty sum. In classic beat 'em up tradition, the story stops there allowing you to pummel your way through the games stages without narrative interruption.

Aces Wild's obvious key focus is it's stylized fast paced aerial combat. The controls consist of a light and heavy attack which are linked to the wild meter located at the top left corner of the screen. The meter is filled with every light attack landed increasing the potency of all your attacks. It's also used for health recovery, and charged attacks. These simple mechanics create a system in which managing your wild meter becomes crucial. You'll find yourself debating on whether to use it for a quick heal, full on charge attack or conserving it just a bit longer for an array of potent light attacks. The three selectable characters also bring a distinct combat style to the table, each with their unique skill set. If you find yourself in a bind consider a new route by selecting another character.

The combat is a bitter sweet. While it is mechanically solid, the level design and enemy encounters undermine it's strengths. One minute you will feel like you are a part of a knuckle sandwich catering service and the next you will find yourself beaten, battered and tossed out on your @$$ like an unruly patron at a biker bar. This often becomes a one sided affair in the later stages when the screen is cluttered with enemies, and one missed dodge results in ten enemy hits. A handful of sword, fists and draggers to the face is a high price to pay for missing one dodge in a cluttered an chaotic melee where sometimes the greatest challenge is keeping track of where your character is at among the action. Enemy's moves don't necessarily evolve either, spamming becomes their default strategy and it becomes extremely irritating when the difficulty is ramped up by cluttering the screen with enemies instead of providing a clever mix of foes that complement one another's attacks and patterns.

Boss battles continue the trend of being frustrating. Like their lesser counterparts, they have a bit of a penchant for spamming the same attacks again and again creating very narrow windows in which to land attacks. Small mistakes and missed dodges are also punished severely. Earlier bosses are formidable at first but quickly become a joke as you learn their patterns. Later encounters ramp up completely taking much of the fun away as they become tedious and annoying. Knowing what to do is one thing, but succeeding is another when everything consuming the screen seems to be at the right spot to put a hurting on you. All is slightly remedied though, as you can select any stage whenever, infinite lives, and the instant respawn with full health after a loss. Still, place fragile valuables in a safe place while playing to ensure their safety.

Leaderboards have recently been added for those looking to ascend them and local mutiplayer is available if you and friend want to tackle the challenge as a team. Co-op play isn't all that exciting though, other then adding a second player on screen the game is exactly the same. If played on a small screen the zooming in and out of the screen can be a pain, making it even more difficult to keep up with what is going on. Unless you have a large monitor and two controllers at hand consider passing on this feature.

Aces Wild channels the style of late 90's Capcom fighting games and side scrolling titles with the UI design and the character animations but is a bit lacking when it comes to detail. Many of the environments feel lifeless and static. There are few interactive objects nor props. Generally, stages are constructed with a photographic backdrop layered with platforms that are crisp and clean but lacking in personality or style. A more dynamic environment could easily add another layer to the static world of Aces Wild and payed better homage to a genre where using objects in the environment as weapons has been a long standing staple. There's also a dearth of detail missing throughout all the characters with little to no animation involved. Fortunately, the soundtrack is well done delivering some fantastic 16bit tracks and sounds.

If Aces Wild Manic Brawling Action gets a sequel a more polished experienced shouldn't be too hard to achieve. The foundation of a great game is present but the overall experience becomes a bit repetitive as the variation in enemies and environment do little to evolve along the way. Manic Brawling Action is a tough game with some infuriating segments, there is no escaping the anger along the ride, but in some ways, that's inherent to the genre. Aces Wild is large dose of nostalgia for a low price, if you're itching for a beat-em up and have run out of other options pick it up. It might just be enough to scratch you right where you need it.

Imagine if Viewtiful Joe, Ninja Gaiden and Touhou had sex.
This is the child that would result

Aces Wild solves the age old problem of arial combat in most brawlers being subpar by making it the focus of the entire game.
The result is that you have a frankly insane amount of things to dodge with an i-frame loaded dodge before using meter-utilizing launchers to deal stupid amounts of damage to enemies in large groups by knocking them into each other.

Be aware the game is hard as balls, however, so if you think this will be an easy romp and treat it as such you'll get proper screwed. Thankfully the entire game is unlocked in both standard and boss rush format, with five difficulty settings and a God Hand style adaptive difficulty system, so you won't suffer too much without an option of simply moving on with shame.

Buy this game.
It's a taste of what a genre can do if we actually push boundaries and blend and build on others instead of spend our time catering to people who don't belong in it in the first place.

Aces Wild: Manic Brawling Action is the sort of game that would have blown my 10 year old mind.

It‚Äôs like a lost classic brawler gem that‚Äôs been hidden in the back of an arcade for years. It plays like a hyperactive beat-em-up with the sensibilities of a saturday morning shonen anime. At its core it‚Äôs a fairly simple button masher, but it moves so fast and has such a ludicrous amount of style that its basic mechanics never stuck out to me, at least at first.

Aces Wild‚Äôs strongest asset is how it feels. The game moves with a bombastic confidence, every character being powerful enough to knock another person around the room like a human pinball and stay in midair by the sheer power of their attacks. If you‚Äôre ever on the ground in Aces Wild you‚Äôre probably doing something wrong, as fights are almost always structured around your ability to zip around like a rocket, sometimes removing the floor entirely as it forces you to chain attacks to stay afloat.

The combination of free-form movement afforded by your ability to go in any direction quickly and accurately, and the perfectly timed slowdown when you take out an enemy creates a feeling of power that is truly something to behold. Functionally you only need to hit one attack button and time enemy strikes so as to dodge and counter, but Aces Wild bombards you so heavily with visual and mechanical feedback for those basic actions that I found it difficult to keep my composure as each fight one-up‚Äôd the last with how over the top things could become.

Aces Wild‚Äôs weakness is that it doesn‚Äôt realize when it‚Äôs time to end before the feeling of embodying a speedy anime badass wears off, with the second half of the game exposing issues of counter timing and some rather cheap enemy patterns. Aside from some interesting level designs, there‚Äôs very little new to see in these later stages, which instead of introducing new enemies simply inflate the health bars and quantity of old ones, leading to drawn out repetitive fights. The bosses also become progressively less inspired, relying on a dull AI pattern of beginning in a disinterested state and then closing every opening as it feverishly beats you down. It was in these fights that I had to control myself from hurling my controller at the screen, as I was placed into fights that sucked all the energy out of the game and seemed almost broken even on the easiest difficulty.

Even at its worst though, Aces Wild never stops being fun. Its later stages are far less balanced and creative than the first half, but its fighting system is such a finely tuned machine that even in its weaker moments there‚Äôs just something awesome about landing a perfect hit and watching an enemy three times your size bounce wildly around the room. When the action is this outrageous, it‚Äôs hard to blame the game for not wanting to stop.

reviewText:
I playtested this, bought it on Humble Store, and now am playing and loving Aces Wild on Steam. Since its Humble Store release I've spent dozens and dozens of hours playing, and my time with this game is far from over.

The controls are easy to pickup but are incredibly precise. You can do crazy combos and fly around the screen with your aerial-powered fighter using a minimal amount of buttons.

The game is challenging but fair. Cliche statement, yes, but true in the case of Aces Wild. Nothing that the game throws at you is outside is unbeatable if you've got the skill.

Do you want a score-attack focused game without those annoying unlockables or DLC? All the content in Aces Wild is available to play from the get go. Do you want to jump straight to the final boss on hardest difficulty? Go for it! It's all good!

Lastly, and possibly what Aces Wild does best, is how much you can simply improve playing the game and how rewarding that feels. The skill ceiling in Aces Wild is absurdly high, and playing through the five difficulties gives a gradual learning curve instead of creating brick walls to bash your head on. Soon enough you'll be flying through dozens if not hundreds of attacks each minute, crashing your fists/swords against enemies so hard *it kills everything nearby*

In short, this game is incredibly challenging, incredibly deep, and incredibly great. GO WILD!!

reviewText:
A 2D beat em up that plays more like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta than Streets of Rage or Final Fight. The action is faster, the characters can move across the screen in a flash, and you can have 10 enemies randomly appear poised to attack.

The crux of the game is balancing your use of your 'Wild' gauge and not dying. As you attack enemies or are attacked your 'Wild' gauge builds up. Past a certain point you can use 'Panic' mode, which depletes the gauge but restores health. Or you can charge up your attacks and inflict some serious damage; you can use up the entire gauge for a single charged attack if you wish. As you attack and build up your gauge, your rank goes up which makes your attacks stronger, but your enemies also become stronger. You want to stay alive as long as possible to continously rank up; using Panic lowers your rank.

The game is pretty fun; but its also pretty simplistic. Gameplay boils down to mashing the attack button and is really more about balancing gauge use and keeping your score up. It's status as an indie title shows: there are 5 level backgrounds in total and the enemy variety is minimal. Your characters have a limited variety of moves and unlike titles within the same genre, like Muramasa (fantastic game, btw) or Double Dragon Neon (BUY IT NOW), you don't get to customize your repertoire of moves and you're pretty much stuck with the same move set. Which would be alright if it were still 1993.

Overall the game is pretty fun, though, but it could use more polish (variety, upgrades, more varied levels). It's pretty damn bare bones as it is, so why the recommendation? Because it doesn't do anything wrong, it just doesn't do enough of it. I can SEE where the appeal might be and I can SEE where the fun might lie, but as it stands it could use more polish and more variety. There's nothing wrong with it as it is, it just doesn't do enough to draw me in and didn't warrant my attention.

5/10:meeehhh. Also, a 5 isn't an automatic ''‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• this title'' in this scenario. A 5 means alright; it isn't an atrocious score. I recommend the title if you can get it under 10 bux; 5=alright. Not a must-have, but alright if you're into the genre and are into the game system and mechanics.

This is a twitch-action combat puzzle game akin to Bangai-O. The focus is on watching enemy AI and trying to figure out the best way to take them down. Combat is fast and feels great - which is good, because that's the basis for the entire game. The game revolves around its Wild meter - you build it with weak attacks and use it to do a heavy one, heal, or fly.

Herein lies Aces Wild's biggest problem - the fly mechanic, which is used to chase enemies and generally travel around every stage, drains your Wild. It drains the longer you hold it, which is an issue because -
A) bosses LOVE to run away and (with the exception of the Guile-type enemy) have ranged attacks that can combo, doing tons of damage -
and B) the latter 2/3rds of the game feature instant death pits. You can air jump infinitely, or tap fly so it uses barely any  meter, but that's a timing window so it's inadvisable - you'll lose focus on enemies and they'll just push you into the pit anyway. I played through this without using the fly mechanic, once I lost to a boss because I drained my meter trying to avoid her floor filling attack that stays until the battle is over. Let me tell you, it was much easier since I wasn't wasting it on foolish endeavors like avoiding damage. It actually becomes unuseable on boss fights like VS Gene.

There's no interim save either, so if you're trying to get a high score run, well, better put some time aside for it. For the rest of us who just want to see the game, you can stage skip, which is nice.

However, the game runs out of unique enemies pretty fast. This wouldn't be an issue if all the screens had interesting or unique solutions, but unfortunately many of them are just here's a million dudes

I'm not sure how to feel about this game. It's clearly trying to be like something made by Treasure and for a while, it really feels like it succeeds in doing this. The core parts of the game feel great, but there's just too many things letting it down.

Those core parts work really well - the movement and combat are simple while having a decent amount of depth. Rapid attacks build up the 'Wild' meter, which is used for both charged attacks and restoring health. It provides an interesting balance that adds a nice risk/reward element. The combat is fun and satisfying when it works out.

Unfortunately, there's a lot dragging this game down. There are only about five types of enemies, with a couple variations on each. This might not be a big deal if the fights felt like they were carefully designed, but later levels usually throw more enemies in at once. One missed dodge can lead to taking a string of hits and losing a large chunk of health. Boss battles have similar issues. Plenty of things simply feel too unforgiving or even unfair. If there was more variety in enemies along with more carefully designed fights, it could be a great game. It just ends up being difficult for dumb reasons, which is a shame because it has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
A good game that could have been a fantastic game.

If you ever wanted to play a 2d version of a game like DMC or Bayonetta, this is probably the exact game you‚Äôre looking for, but have never heard of. Aces wild is an interesting mix up between crazy action beat um up, and old school side scrolling beat um up, That does the former much better than it does the latter.

It‚Äôs crazy to think that an Indy made game like this, could have out classed so many games made by major publishers, if it weren‚Äôt for a few key features missing from it‚Äôs incredibly fluid, over the top play style. The games basic controls consist of two main attacks, a dash, and a guard, The light attack button is your standard combo attack, and the other is the heavy crash attack button. The game also has an extremely interesting mechanic that holds it all together, called wild meter. The wild meter fills up as you preform combos. The fun thing about it is that it has a large variety of uses, wild can be used for preforming crash attacks, for charging  crash attacks, crash counters, extended dashing, and activating ‚Äúpanic‚Äù. Not only this, but the more wild you have the more base damage your combos do, which constantly keeps you thinking about how much wild you spend as opposed to keeping it in to do more combo damage to your enemy‚Äôs. Also unlike a lot of other games, all of these skills are essential to master, and none of them feel pointless. The game has a great deal of enemy variety, all of which demand a different way of fighting. The weaker foes in the game can be mowed down with basic combos, but it gets really tricky when you have to fight enemies who are not affected by hit stun because of their shields, or enemy‚Äôs that spam projectiles, and others that counter. The game makes you think about what enemy‚Äôs you want to prioritize, as well as what you want to use your wild on. Sometimes it will be more beneficial to fight a good long fight while dogging all incoming attacks mixing up your basic, and crash attacks to gain wild faster. Or sometimes it will be better rolling into the part of the level, and destroying everything with one fully charged crash attack, causing all your enemy‚Äôs to knock into each other at full force. Or you just might want to play it safe till you get enough wild to use a panic, which restores a great deal of health depending on how much wild you have.

Another huge part of the games great combat, is how the dashing and dogging work so well, it never gets old watching your enemy‚Äôs fly to the other side of the screen, and catching right up to them, in a split second just to keep the beat down going, then sending the body whirling into the rest of the enemy‚Äôs. It also serves as a great tool to catch, and pummel many of the bosses before they are able to perform an attack, if they don‚Äôt have a guard up. It‚Äôs also nice to see that dogging has an extended window of invincibility which makes it easier to preform counters which comes in handy to beating most of the games earlier foes. The game does a fantastic job at keeping the action going even at some of its more chaotic points, dashing around preforming a combo, finishing a guy of and diving right into the rest of the group with a fully charged crash attack is satisfying. The game is a complete joy to play, and delivers on making the player feel like a badass, as the action never breaks, till the last few stages.

Unfortunately as much as I want to gush about the games combat it has some extremely large draw backs as the game moves on. Now it should be said that these games are difficult by nature, but towards the end of the game, you can be punished with death for the slightest mistakes. It‚Äôs all fun and games till you have around one hundred enemies on screen, and twenty of them are throwing projectiles at you, making it look more like a smup than a beat um up. At this stage one missed dodge will open you up to a fifty or more hit combo taking half your life away, only to wind up in the same position less than a second later because you failed to take out any enemies, because they were too busy styling all over your face. It‚Äôs also not fun to run into twenty or so enemy‚Äôs that all have shields, and aren‚Äôt affected by hit stun, and are essentially invulnerable, while they mercilessly hack away at you. In fights like these, the games mechanics begin to break down. Counters become worthless; with only limited invincibility leaving you open to punishment after only killing a few guys. And crash attacks become almost unusable, as you may never get even the one second it takes to charge them up to guard break. And even if you do, it‚Äôs easy to wiff, and wastes your entire wild meter on noting, while you put your controller down, and get styled on into oblivion. Just whiffing a crash attack at certain times can spell instant death, because you may not get a good chance to gain enough wild back to guard break. The games main problem is that it doesn‚Äôt include any kind of upgrade system that is seen in any of the games 3d counter parts. The game makes itself into a perfect example of, why such things are needed in a manic brawler. Being able to customize how you fight keeps it so you can keep playing the game the way you want to play, instead of the game playing you, as you are forced to conform to enemy patterns, or die. It would have been fantastic to put points into the counter mechanic so that you could remain invincible while you perform a crash counter, so you know you‚Äôre not going to burn your entire wild meter for nothing. Being able to upgrade key mechanics is a must for games like this, 3d or 2d. It just can‚Äôt stay true to its old school arcade street brawler roots, where you don‚Äôt get any kind of upgrades, and you have to rely on basic mechanics. If things stay to basic, the enemy verity begins to cap out at a point, and you end up with a game that just poor‚Äôs on the hurt to artificially extend its length.

Another one of the games sore spots is its presentation it‚Äôs environments are clean, but dull, character animation‚Äôs outside of aces, are very poor, and aces are very lacking, and enemy designs are very hit or miss. You only get two playable characters with only minor differences. The game is only about seven to eight hours long, and the game has no reliability, or online play at all. However the music is pretty good for the most part. Over all it‚Äôs an amazing game at its core, I‚Äôve never played a 2d game as fast nor as furious as this one, but its un polished no matter where you look at it. 7/10

reviewText:
Sidescrolling action at its finest - this game comes highly recommended, especially for the price. I haven't played it for long, but I've enjoyed every minute of it's button-mashing action. I grew up enjoying many a cartoon-looking side scroller, and this one not only delivers in the nostalgia department, there's definitely lots of fun to be had for newbies.

The game looks like it should have been made in the 90s, but this isn't a bad thing. Genuinely good arcade games have been scarce of late, especially the side scroll, button mashing, high scoring sort. Games like Cadillacs and Dinosaurs and Final Fight were hits because of the ridiculous number of enemies you had to beat down until your fingers hurt and the insane boss fights. This game is no exception.

The action is smooth, comboing enemies into all corners of the screen is fun, and if you're worried it's too easy, don't. If you're like me, you'll go down a few times, but still want to come back for another round. You can also adjust the difficulty, so you're never short of a challenge. Each time I play I get a better feel for it, so after an hour or so you'll settle into a rythm, dodging ninjas and counter attacking until your wild meter is nice and full.

Kudos to the game creators! They've got a hit here. It still feels like it needs a little refinement or more detail but it's good as it is. I'd give it a solid 8/10 - a must buy.

Make sure your controller (or keyboard) can take the hammering. You're going to want to keep that Wild meter full for the extra damage, flashy effects and ricocheting enemies ;)

The genre and the trailer is pretty self explanatory. This is like an old school beat-em up/brawler game. It may remind you of games like Streets of Rage, Golden Axe, River City Ransom, Comix Zone, Double Dragon, Battletoads.......

This is a very satisfying game if you let yourself get to know it. It's a simple design with a detailed gameplay experience. The controls are simple and so is your goal. The experience, however, WILL challenge you. It demands all of your skill... anything less and you will be punished. This is a high paced action game that throws a lot of obstacles in your face (and all at once in some cases). It will intimidate you, frustrate you, and mock you... but in the end you may feel a sense of proudness and badass-ery when you clear that stage and/or boss, even after dying numerous times.
Even after beating it, which I honestly wasn't sure I was going to be able to do, I still find myself coming back to it because even after becoming better at the game I'm still challenged by it (in a mostly fun way). There's even a few more masochistic difficulty levels for the die hards out there. The gameplay feels fresh every time I play it because I try to play better than last time for the sake of personal achievement. To me this equals a game that was well done.
This game also has an awesome soundtrack to go with smashing up your enemies. Can't really say more than that.

8/10 is what I'd say. Buy it.

It doesn't get a 9 because the stage 6 boss is designed poorly for the overall game experience, I think it ruins the game a little, it doesn't match the skill pace. Plus the final boss felt like a joke compared to the other 6.

reviewText:
I'm not sure how to feel about this game. It's clearly trying to be like something made by Treasure and for a while, it really feels like it succeeds in doing this. The core parts of the game feel great, but there's just too many things letting it down.

Those core parts work really well - the movement and combat are simple while having a decent amount of depth. Rapid attacks build up the 'Wild' meter, which is used for both charged attacks and restoring health. It provides an interesting balance that adds a nice risk/reward element. The combat is fun and satisfying when it works out.

Unfortunately, there's a lot dragging this game down. There are only about five types of enemies, with a couple variations on each. This might not be a big deal if the fights felt like they were carefully designed, but later levels usually throw more enemies in at once. One missed dodge can lead to taking a string of hits and losing a large chunk of health. Boss battles have similar issues. Plenty of things simply feel too unforgiving or even unfair. If there was more variety in enemies along with more carefully designed fights, it could be a great game. It just ends up being difficult for dumb reasons, which is a shame because it has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
Great game for fans of extremely fast paced and hectic action games. The game adds a very unique and interesting meter which builds up as you attack more aggresively, the meter results in your attack power increasing but it also makes enemies more aggresive towards you. You can lower the meter by using charged attacks for serious damage (think of it like releasing energy that you built up). This meter keeps combat interesting and manic and makes the game extremely fun.

The controls are perfect, without a single tutorial I found the controls easy to understand, they felt intuitive, easy to get the hang of and very natural. However, just because the controls are easy does not mean the game is - the game is very hard and is constantly exciting and addicting.

I'm not going to write a full review just yet since the developer is still hard at working fixing bugs and improving the game - one particularly annoying bug is that the game occasionally crashes, it is frequent enough to be annoying but not frequent enough to become unplayable.

At this stage, I'd give a weary recommendation - don't expect a finished product if you think about buying it. However, I do have confidence that you will enjoy what you play of it and that the game will become something very special once the bugs are ironed out.

reviewText: I'm a little torn on this one.  The game is marketed as a brawler, but it isn't one really.  It's very floaty and has bullet hell elements. As highlighted in the trailer, the music really is awesome, so if you're looking for a game with an awesome soundtrack, there you go.\n\nStory?  Meh.  Characters?  Bleh.  Plot or intrigue?  Nah.  Then again, those aren't entirely necessary in action games.  The game is simple in delivery, but it takes time to really learn how to play it well.
